STATE OF MICHIGAN
GRETCHEN WHITMER DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES ELIZABETH HERTEL
GOVERNOR LANSING DIRECTOR
August 23, 2022
Max Harris
St. John's Home Residential
2355 Knapp St.
Grand Rapids, MI 49505
RE: License #: CI410305582
Investigation #: 2022C0228002
St. John's Home Residential
Dear Mr. Harris:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
 How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
 Specific time frames for each violation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 Indicate how continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 Be signed and dated.
Please note that violations of any licensing rules are also violations of the MISEP and
your contract.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the Area Manager at (616) 204-6992.

Sincerely,
Shannon (Shay) Mavis, Licensing Consultant
MDHHS\Division of Child Welfare Licensing
427 E. Alcott
Kalamazoo, MI 49001
(269) 243-2725
enclosure

MICHIGAN DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
DIVISION OF CHILD WELFARE LICENSING
SPECIAL INVESTIGATION REPORT
I. IDENTIFYING INFORMATION
License #: CI410305582
Investigation #: 2022C0228002
Complaint Receipt Date: 07/20/2022
Investigation Initiation Date: 07/20/2022
Report Due Date: 09/18/2022
Licensee Name: DA Blodgett for Children
Licensee Address: 805 Leonard NE
Grand Rapids, MI 49503
Licensee Telephone #: (616) 361-5227
Administrator: Max Harris, Administrator
Licensee Designee: Mary Muliett, Designee
Name of Facility: St. John's Home Residential
Facility Address: 2355 Knapp St.
Grand Rapids, MI 49505
Facility Telephone #: (616) 361-5227
Original Issuance Date: 01/04/2010
License Status: REGULAR
Effective Date: 03/09/2021
Expiration Date: 03/08/2023
Capacity: 40
Program Type: CHILD CARING INSTITUTION, PRIVATE
1

II. ALLEGATION(S)
Violation
Established?
Since 7/8/22, there have been 3 incidents of youth taking keys Yes
from staff. Youth have used keys to access a medicine cabinet
and houses.
III. METHODOLOGY
07/20/2022 Special Investigation Intake
2022C0228002
07/20/2022 Special Investigation Initiated - Telephone
Discussion allegations with assigned consultant and Area
Manager.
07/20/2022 Contact - Document Received
Reviewed MiSACWIS incident reports #138730195, 138910194
and 138920196.
07/21/2022 Contact - Document Sent
Email notification of investigation to youth's foster care workers.
07/21/2022 Contact - Document Received
Email received from foster care worker for Youth A.
07/22/2022 Inspection Completed On-site
Unannounced visit to facility. Met with Chief Administrator and
Director. Reviewed video and agency incident reports.
07/25/2022 Contact - Document Received
Email received from foster care worker for Youth B.
07/26/2022 Contact - Document Received
Received information that Youth A had been moved from the
facility as of 7/25/2022. Email contact received from the foster care
worker for Youth A stating he went AWOL the same date.
07/26/2022 Contact - Document Received
Received and reviewed the facility's Medication Storage
Procedure and the AWOL events for the youth between 7/8/22-
7/15/22.
07/27/2022 Contact - Document Received
Received staff files from facility.
07/28/2022 Contact - Telephone call made
Completed interviews via phone with Director, 2 Supervisors, 4
staff and 1 youth.
08/08/2022 Contact - Document Received
Reviewed GRPD police report dated 7/11/22 (#22-038677).
08/08/2022 Contact - Document Received
Reviewed staff files provided by the facility.
08/08/2022 Contact - Document Received
Received email from foster care worker reporting that Youth A is
still AWOL.
2

08/08/2022 Contact - Document Received
Reviewed RUSP for Youth A dated 7/22/22 (report period 5/8/22-
7/22/22).
08/10/2022 Contact - Face to Face
Completed interviews on-site at the facility with Youth C and Youth
D.
08/12/2022 Contact - Face to Face
Completed pre-exit meeting with Chief Administrator and Director
on-site at the facility.
08/18/2022 Inspection Completed – BCAL Sub. Compliance
ALLEGATION:
Since 7/8/22, there have been 3 incidents of youth taking keys from staff. Youth
have used keys to access a medicine cabinet and houses.
INVESTIGATION:
Interviews:
Assigned DCWL Consultant/Complainant was interviewed via TEAMS on
7/20/22. Consultant reported she reviewed 3 MISACWIS incident reports dated
7/8/22, 7/11/22 and 7/13/22, which all noted that youth took staff member’s keys.
The incident reports noted that youth were accessing the medication room,
medication cart, took youth allowances and/or entering the other houses on campus.
Staff 1 was interviewed via telephone on 7/28/22. On 7/11/22, Staff 1 was in the
medication room and was about to pass a PRN medication to a youth. A coworker
told him that they needed support out in the yard for youth approaching Renucci.
Staff 1 left the key inserted in the medication cart in the rush of things but made sure
to shut the locked medication room door. Staff 1 stated because the youth had the
staff key, they were able to access the medication room, and had access to the
medication cart because the key was left in it. Staff 1 said there is not a policy
specifically referencing keys, however, there is a culture at the facility that keys need
to be protected, safe and always with staff. Staff 1 admitted to making a mistake and
is aware medications need to be double locked at all times, which means the
medication cart needs to be locked and needs to remain in the locked medication
room.
Staff 2 was interviewed via telephone on 7/28/22. Staff 2 reported on 7/13/22, he
was attempting to lock the staff bathroom and Youth A grabbed his keys out of his
hand. Youth A, Youth B, Youth C and Youth D were tossing the keys amongst each
other while approximately 4 staff and the supervisor tried to retrieve them. Youth D
retrieved the keys and gave them back to Staff 2, but Staff 2 noticed his staff key
was missing. About an hour later, the youth entered the medication room in Renucci,
but were not able to access the medication cart due to staff presence. Staff 2
reported the residents had 2 staff keys, but the police were called and were able to
retrieve the keys that day.
3

Staff 3 was interviewed via telephone on 7/28/22. Staff 3 reported on 7/8/22
Youth A took his keys off the table while he was doing paperwork. Staff 3 heard the
youth state they wanted the allowance money from the top drawer of the medication
cart for a drug deal. Staff 3 reported Youth A accessed the staff bathroom,
medication room, medication cart and snack closet. Staff 3 reported Youth A
retrieved the allowance money and gave back Staff 3’s personal keys but kept Staff
3’s staff key and proceeded to go AWOL. Staff 3 said his key was retrieved
approximately 2-3 days later. Staff 3 is unsure where allowances are kept now, but
knows they are no longer kept in the medication cart. Staff 3 noted medications are
to be double locked, which means the medication cart must be locked at all times
and remain in the locked medication room.
Staff 4 was interviewed via telephone on 7/28/22. Staff 4 reported youth have
been taking keys out of staff’s pockets, out of staff’s hands and look for any other
opportunities they may have to take staff keys. Staff 4 reported she retrieved Staff
3’s key after Youth A and Youth C took it and went AWOL for 2-3 days. Staff 4
reported during that 2–3-day timeframe, Youth A and Youth C continued to return to
the facility to use the keys to enter the commons building and different houses to
steal items.
Supervisor 1 was interviewed via telephone on 7/28/22. Supervisor 1 reported
Youth A took a staff’s keys on 7/13/22 and Supervisor 1 was attempting to retrieve
them. The youth told staff and Supervisor 1 that the keys were thrown onto the roof
of Cebelak, but that was determined to be false after staff checked. Supervisor 1
was unsure if the key was ever retrieved.
Supervisor 2 was interviewed via telephone on 7/28/22. Supervisor 2 reported on
7/8/22, he accidently locked his keys in the medication room and used Staff 3’s keys
to access the medication room to retrieve them. Supervisor 2 reported after he
placed Staff 3’s keys back on the table, Youth A took them. Youth A accessed the
staff bathroom, retrieved the key for the medication cart key box, then entered the
medication room and was able to open/access the medication cart. Supervisor 2
reported he and staff were trying to get the keys back, but the youth were blocking
the door and Youth A was trying to assault staff. Youth A and C took the X-box and
allowance money but did not attempt to access any medications in the medication
cart. Supervisor 2 reported he retrieved the medication cart key and Staff 3’s
personal keys, but Youth A and Youth C went AWOL with Staff 3’s staff key.
Chief Administrator and Director were interviewed face-to-face at the facility
on 7/22/22 and 8/12/22. They reported the staff keys open the other buildings on
campus as well as the doors in the homes, including the medication rooms and staff
bathrooms. The locked medication carts are in the locked medication rooms. The
keys to open the locked medication carts are in a locked box attached to the
medication carts. The keys to open the locked box are in the staff bathrooms in each
of the homes.
4

Youth A was AWOL on 7/22/22 when a face-to-face interview was attempted.
On 7/25/22, Youth A was moved from the facility, went AWOL and has been AWOL
since that date. An interview was unable to be conducted with Youth A.
Youth B was interviewed via telephone on 7/28/22. Youth B reported staff keep
their keys in their pockets and kids try to get them or staff drop their keys and kids
try to get them. Youth B reported he did not know when these situations occurred,
what happened or who was involved.
Youth C was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on 8/8/22. Youth C reported
staff keys can unlock any door on campus and normally staff keep their keys in their
pockets. Youth C described the situation as viewed in the video on 7/8/22. Youth C
reported they wanted staff keys to take money as well as computers from Commons
and Renucci so they could communicate with someone on Facebook to come pick
them up.
Youth D was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on 8/8/22. Youth D reported
Youth A and Youth B came up with a plan to steal staff keys to allow access to
Renucci so they could take money and other items, go AWOL and obtain drugs.
Youth D reported the youth were targeting newer staff’s keys because they did not
think they would know the rules or how to handle the situations. Youth D advised all
the youth know where each of the keys are located to gain access to the medication
cart, so if youth get a staff key, they know the steps they need to follow next. Youth
D reported youths’ personal snacks and calming boxes are in the staff bathroom,
which is also where one of the keys for the medication cart is hanging. Youth would
ask for these items to allow easier access to that key. Youth D stated staff always
keep the medication cart and medication room locked.
Video Reviewed:
 Video footage of Cebelak House from 7/8/22 was reviewed on 7/22/22. Staff
3 gave Supervisor 2 his keys. Supervisor 2 went into the medication room,
grabbed something, walked back out and shut the door. Supervisor 2 put
Staff 3’s keys on the table in the milieu where Staff 3 sat completing
paperwork. Youth A took the keys off the table and Youth A, Youth C and
Youth D used the key to enter the medication room. Youth A could not open
the medication cart with that key. Youth C and Youth D blocked Supervisor 2
from entering the medication room. The youth took the X-box out of the
medication room and went through other items while another youth blocked
staff from entering the room. Youth C left the medication room and came back
with a second key that opened the box on the medication cart that contained
the medication cart key. Youth A and Youth C opened the medication cart
and took money out of the pouches in the top drawer. They left the room and
exited through the front entrance of the house. Staff were seen in the milieu
talking and attempting to engage youth. A couple minutes later, Youth A
reentered the home, went back into the medication room, and took additional
5

money out of the top drawer of the medication cart. Youth A & Youth C placed
the money and X-box in backpacks while staff were seen still talking to and
trying to engage youth. Youth C gave Staff 3 his personal keys, but kept the
staff key and exited the house with Youth A.
 Video footage of Renucci House from 7/11/22 was reviewed on 7/22/22. Staff
1 was in the medication room with the medication cart unlocked. Staff 1 exited
the medication room and shut the door but left the key to the medication cart
in the lock with the cart unlocked. Youth A and Youth C entered the
medication room, opened the top drawer of the medication cart, and took
money out of the pouches. Staff tried to enter the room, but Youth C was
barricading the door. Youth A and Youth C exited the medication room. Staff
4 entered the medication room, relocked the medication cart and exited the
room.
Documents Reviewed:
 D.A. Blodgett St. John’s Medication Storage Procedure (rev. 10/2019):
o Medications must be kept double locked at all times.
o Never leave the medication cart unattended once it is unlocked.
o Medication Carts cannot be used for any other purpose than storing
and passing medications.
 Agency internal incident report dated 7/8/22 was mostly consistent with the
video footage viewed. One part of the report not seen on video notes Youth A
punched a staff member in the chest when the staff member followed Youth A
outside after he exited the home the first time.
 MiSACWIS incident report #138730195 dated 7/8/22 was consistent with
Supervisor 2’s interview as well as the video footage viewed.
 Grand Rapids Police Department report (#22-038677) dated 7/11/22 stated
that during police presence, 3 vehicle keys and 1 main master campus key
were retrieved from residents.
 MiSACWIS incident report #138910194 dated 7/11/22 was consistent with
staff interviews and video footage viewed.
 Agency internal incident report dated 7/13/22 stated Youth A took Staff 2’s
keys off his person and ran in and out of the house with the keys. Supervisor
1 tried to take the keys from Youth A but was unsuccessful. Youth A entered
the medication room but could not access the medication cart due to staff
presence. Youth A gave Staff 2’s keys back to him, but the staff key was
missing.
 MISACWIS incident report #138920196 dated 7/13/22 was consistent with
staff and supervisor interviews.
6

 Staff 1’s and Staff 2’s personnel file - There were no disciplinary record. Staff
1 and Staff 2 completed trainings related to medication storage and passing,
with the most recent being completed on 5/25/22.
 Staff 3’s personnel file - There was no disciplinary record. Staff 3 completed
training on agency policies/procedures on 6/10/22 and completed training on
medication administration on 7/18/22.
 Staff 4’s personnel file - There was no disciplinary record. Staff 4 completed
trainings related to medication storage and passing, with the most recent
being completed on 5/10/22.
 Supervisor 1’s personnel file contained 2 disciplinary records. One discipline
record noted that there were 6 incidents in which Supervisor 1 failed to
document, sign or update medication information for youth files. Supervisor 1
completed trainings related to medication storage and passing, with the most
recent being completed on 5/25/22.
 Supervisor 2’s personnel file – There was no disciplinary record. Supervisor 2
completed trainings related to medication storage and passing, with the most
recent being completed on 1/6/22 and then on 7/18/22.
APPLICABLE RULE
R 400.4142 Health services; policies and procedures.
(1) An institution shall establish and follow written health service
policies and procedures addressing all of the following:
7

(d) Storage of medications.
ANALYSIS: The facility is found in noncompliance as Staff 1 left the
medication cart unlocked/unattended and the facility was storing
youth allowances in the medication cart, which are both against
the facility’s Medication Storage Procedure.
TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE:
It is recommended the facility explore options for storage of youth’s
personal snacks, calming boxes, and youth allowances.
It is recommended the facility explore storage options for the key
that unlocks the key box for the medication cart (currently stored in
the staff bathroom). One suggestion might be a code-style lock box
to add an additional layer of protection.
The facility should determine what the procedure will be if youth
obtain keys in the future.
CONCLUSION: VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
IV. RECOMMENDATION
I recommend upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, no change be
made to the license status of this child caring institution
8/18/22
________________________________________
Shannon (Shay) Mavis Date
Licensing Consultant
Approved By:
August 23, 2022
________________________________________
Jessica VandenHeuvel Date
Area Manager
8
